issues.title: Rampant Land Disputes and Fraud
issues.summary: Land-related disputes constitute over 70% of civil cases in Bangladesh courts, with fraudulent documents and multiple claims causing widespread injustice.
issues.currentSituation: Bangladesh lacks a comprehensive digital land registry. Paper-based records are susceptible to forgery, and the process of verifying land ownership is time-consuming, expensive, and prone to corruption. An estimated 4 million land-related cases are pending in courts.
affectedGroups: Low-income families vulnerable to land grabbing
consequences: Billions of taka lost in legal fees annually
Violence and deaths over land disputes
Delayed economic development projects
Erosion of trust in legal system
potentialTechInterventions: Mobile app for land record verification
relatedResources: World Bank Report on Land Administration in Bangladesh
Transparency International Bangladesh Land Governance Study

issues.title: Limited Healthcare Access in Rural Areas
issues.summary: The majority of Bangladesh's population lacks access to quality healthcare due to shortage of doctors, inadequate facilities, and geographic barriers.
issues.currentSituation: Bangladesh has approximately 1 doctor per 2,000 people, well below WHO recommendations. Specialist doctors are concentrated in Dhaka and major cities. Rural health centers often lack basic equipment and qualified staff. Patients travel hours to reach quality care.
consequences: High maternal and infant mortality rates
Preventable deaths from treatable diseases
Financial burden from travel and treatment costs
Delayed diagnosis of serious conditions
potentialTechInterventions: Health worker mobile apps for community health
Medicine delivery and inventory management systems
relatedResources: Ministry of Health Digital Health Strategy

issues.title: Education Quality Gap Between Urban and Rural
issues.summary: Significant disparity exists in education quality between urban and rural schools, perpetuating cycles of poverty and limiting opportunities.
issues.currentSituation: Rural schools face teacher shortages, lack of qualified instructors, inadequate learning materials, and poor infrastructure. Urban students have access to better schools, private tutoring, and digital resources. This gap widens with each grade level.
consequences: Lower pass rates in national examinations
Limited higher education opportunities
Reduced employment prospects
Brain drain from rural to urban areas
potentialTechInterventions: Free online learning platforms in Bangla

issues.title: Severe Traffic Congestion in Dhaka
issues.summary: Dhaka is one of the world's most congested cities, with traffic jams causing massive economic losses and reduced quality of life.
issues.currentSituation: Average traffic speed in Dhaka has dropped to 7 km/hour during peak times. Citizens spend 3-4 hours daily in traffic. Economic losses estimated at à§³37,000 crore annually. Lack of integrated public transport, poor traffic management, and rapid urbanization compound the problem.
consequences: Lost productivity worth billions annually
Increased air pollution and health issues
Delayed emergency response times
Mental health impact and stress
relatedResources: World Bank Dhaka Urban Transport Study

issues.title: Corruption in Public Services
issues.summary: Citizens face bribery demands when accessing basic public services like getting documents, permits, or utilities connected.
issues.currentSituation: According to surveys, over 60% of citizens report paying bribes for public services. Common areas include passport offices, land offices, utility connections, and law enforcement. Average households spend significant amounts on unofficial payments annually.
consequences: Increased cost of living for ordinary citizens
Discouragement of business and investment
Erosion of public trust in institutions
Perpetuation of inequality
potentialTechInterventions: Automated approval systems to reduce discretion
